info.game_comments:
First game of Season 2.
Returning champions (for this week only) were placed at the far right podium.
The new "buzz-in" (after Alex finishes reading the clue) rule was introduced.

(1, 1).clue: At various times, he & all 5 of his brothers were nicknamed "Ike"

(2, 1).clue: Sherlock Holmes novel about a devilish dog

(3, 1).clue: No matter how you slice it, it's "brot" in German

(5, 1).clue: The appropriately named Pepe Le Pew is this animal

(6, 1).clue: Alphabetically 1st of the days of the week, it's usually last of the work week

(1, 2).clue: Springtime ritual started by Pres. Hayes on the White House lawn

(2, 2).clue: He knocked over the screen concealing the Wizard of Oz

(3, 2).clue: From the Latin meaning "to serve", it's the soup that starts an Italian meal

(5, 2).clue: This super hero was originally called "Super Mouse"

(1, 3).clue: For the presidential portraits, Gilbert Stuart stuffed his sunken cheeks with cotton

(2, 3).clue: In this book, Nick Charles' Asta is a schnauzer, but in films was played by a wire-haired terrier

(3, 3).clue: Cookie from northern France made of sugar, egg white & almonds; it got its name from Italian for macaroni

(5, 3).clue: Name of George of the Jungle's pet ape

(1, 4).clue: (Audio -- musical clue)President who preferred Chopin's waltzes to this, his musical "trademark":

(2, 4).clue: Garryowen is the "bloody mangy mongrel" in the "Cyclops" episode of this James Joyce novel

(3, 4).clue: The distinctive starchy ingredient in Chinese dishes with "mein" in the name

(5, 4).clue: Though he never married, Paramount's Popeye had this many "nephews" who all looked just like him

(6, 4).clue: Alphabetically 1st of the planets, it can be seen without a telescope

(1, 5).clue: In 1908, 5 years before getting the job, he wrote a book titled "The President of the United States"

(3, 5).clue: Tropical fruit called "The Fruit of India", it's the main ingredient in a popular chutney

(5, 5).clue: Helen Kane sued Max Fleischer, claiming this character's name & voice were copied from her

(6, 5).clue: Alphabetically the 1st signer of the Declaration of Independence, he's also first alphabetically of presidents

(1, 1).clue: His "signature" is an elegantly scripted YSL

(2, 1).clue: The term "renaissance" is from a French word meaning this

(3, 1).clue: A Marine Corps camp, or appropriate footwear for one

(4, 1).clue: Use of reasonable force to protect oneself is called this

(5, 1).clue: This New England state is about the same size as the other 5 combined

(6, 1).clue: In the U.S., it's traditionally the best night of the year to see ghosts

(1, 2).clue: This American costumer revealed the mysteries of Cher's navel weekly on "The Sonny & Cher Show"

(2, 2).clue: A 1490 census of Rome showed 15% of the female population registered in this "profession"

(3, 2).clue: You try to do it to a putt or an enemy boat

(4, 2).clue: For only time in U.S. history, he had Congress suspend habeus corpus during the Civil War

(5, 2).clue: Shortest state motto, "Hope!", appropriately belongs to this New England state

(6, 2).clue: He, not the president, is said to haunt Ford's Theater in Washington, D.C.

(1, 3).clue: Austrian princess who created the look of the simple wrap jersey dress of the '70s

(2, 3).clue: Some say he based the ruthless ruler in "The Prince" on Cesare Borgia

(3, 3).clue: 1st four-letter word in the Lord's Prayer

(4, 3).clue: Court session when a prisoner hears charges against him & enters plea

(5, 3).clue: The first & last of 6 New England-born presidents both had this first name

(6, 3).clue: At Windsor Castle, this Tudor queen supposedly haunts the queen's library

(1, 4).clue: American designer Willi Smith's ready-to-wear label

(3, 4).clue: The 9th letter in the Greek alphabet, it's come to mean "a small amount"

(4, 4).clue: The Supreme Court said electrocuting someone again after the chair failed once wasn't this

(5, 4).clue: In '64, it became the 1st in the nation to have a state lottery

(6, 4).clue: Shakespearean monarch visited by 11 ghosts of his victims before the Battle of Bosworth Field

(1, 5).clue: Although over 80, she's still consulting editor of Vogue magazine

(2, 5).clue: His brilliant 16th century translation of the Bible into German became the basis for modern German

(3, 5).clue: Spelled forward it's how you feel, backwards it spells disaster

(4, 5).clue: Specific purpose stated in 2nd Amendment for right to bear arms
(4, 5).correct response: for the furnishment of a militia

(5, 5).clue: Sikorsky built 1st one-rotor helicopter in this state, which still makes most helicopters

(6, 5).clue: A hideous Arabian ghost who steals corpses, it's come to mean any grave robber

(0, 0).clue: Among the women prominent in this sport are Rachel McLish, Lori Bowen & Cory Everson
